body: Amid glistening greens and pyramids of produce in the small store in Flushing, Queens, that he hoped would insure his family's prosperity, Sun Yong Back assesses a future that has suddenly dimmed. The odds seem as long as his workdays. As New York City's economy turned anemic, he says, his sales have dropped by more than 30 percent. Taxes are
title: Korean Entrepreneurs Find Their Dream Is Tarnishing

body: The "Christmas Lights in Brooklyn" tour, an after-dark excursion from Manhattan to view the decorated houses of southeast Brooklyn, will be resumed for the seventh year tomorrow by Singer's Tours. The bus will wait for passengers (25-person limit) at 325 East 41st Street each evening through Jan. 4; it leaves at 5:30 and returns at midnight. Tour
title: Brooklyn's Holiday Lights

body: A YEAR after the first reports of defaults by sponsors who converted rental buildings into cooperatives, the number of troubled buildings has risen sharply and thousands of middle-income New York City apartment owners are caught in a financial squeeze. Having assessed the extent of the problem, public officials are questioning the viability of
title: Toll of Troubled Conversions Is Rising

body: LIKE the IRT express, restaurant developers in recent years have bypassed most stops on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. But not Arthur Cutler, whose places attract standing-room-only crowds. When fish started becoming popular in the early 1980's, Mr. Cutler was ready with Docks, a moderately priced fish house. With people hungry for alternatives
title: DE GUSTIBUS; Upper West Side's Host With the Most

body: New York City's sheriff and 25 deputies raided 11 stores in the Fordham Road business district in the Bronx yesterday, shutting one and taking money from cash registers to collect on unpaid summonses for littering. By the end of the two-hour sweep, deputies carried a black plastic box heavy with more than $40,000, much of it in rolls of quarters
title: 11 Bronx Stores Raided as Sheriff Continues Effort to Collect Fines

body: A Pakistani man was assaulted by a marine and a companion on a Brooklyn-bound subway train early Saturday, the transit police reported, listing the incident as a bias attack. The victim, Khawaja Pasha, 31 years old, of the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, received a black eye and a few bruises, said a transit police spokesman, Sgt. Robert
title: 2 Held in Bias Attack on Pakistani in Subway

body: To the Editor Your article on Manhattan Beach on Sept. 16 states that the "biggest problem is popularity with outsiders [ my emphasis ] in the summer. To ease congestion streets are off-limits to parking . . . ." This situation has always infuriated me. Look at the abutting Brighton Beach area if you need a definition of "congestion" -- summer and
title: Manhattan Beach

body: The playwright Sophie Treadwell died at the age of 85 in 1970, "but everywhere in her play, you keep discovering Sophie," the director Michael Greif was saying about her expressionist drama, "Machinal." "Whenever you're in doubt, Sophie makes it so very easy for you. She thought of everything." But perhaps she never envisioned that her forgotten
title: Play Proves Its Point in Obscurity

body: A GROUP of Soviet executives, including the chief accountant of a Siberian tire plant, a lawyer and a division chief for a machine-building plant, have arrived in the county to study firsthand the dynamics of America's market-driven economy. Thirty-eight men and three women began a monthlong executive management program two weeks ago at Iona
title: For Russians, Firsthand Lessons In Capitalism

body: LEAD: Night after night, resolve in their hearts and walkie-talkies in their hands, Ed Powell and James Burns set off on their self-appointed rounds. On rooftops glittering with crushed crack vials, in dark hallways littered with soda cans, along streets strewn with empty-eyed and defiant boys, they patrol a neighborhood in crisis. Night after
title: On Dark Streets, 'Eyes and Ears' for the Law

body: LEAD: THE day's agenda - visiting a bus garage and sewer treatment plant in Yonkers and a garbage incinerator in Peekskill - would not have thrilled most visitors to Westchester County. But for a delegation of 14 mayors from the Soviet Union who were spending two weeks in the United States, it was close to perfect. THE day's agenda - visiting a bus
title: Bus Garage To Incinerator: An Itinerary For Russians

body: LEAD: May link recalls her first trolley rides to Manhattan Beach with her mother in 1912. For five cents, they took hour-long trips from working-class Williamsburg to the Brooklyn enclave of millionaires' mansions. title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Manhattan Beach

body: LEAD: To the Editor: As the former commander of the 60th Precinct in Brooklyn, I can say with all honesty that the best defense is a strong offense in deterring crime. title: In New York, Walking the Beat Isn't Enough

title: A FATHER'S PAWN

title: Subway Police Patrols for Students to Begin

body: LEAD: What makes Brooklyn clubs so nice is similar to what makes the borough itself pleasant: smaller crowds, less pressure and more variety than in Manhattan. title: Pop/Jazz; Tomorrow's Stars Today In Brooklyn's Small Clubs

body: LEAD: May 16, 1989: ''Time of the Gypsies,'' Emir Kusturica's first film since the awardwinning ''When Father Was Away on Business'' (1985) has its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival to cheers that swell into a five-minute standing ovation. The elation of the film's cast can be heard up and down the Croisette till dawn, as gypsy musicians play
title: Gypsy Life Beguiles a Film Maker
